inlineContent.text: When writing unit tests for view models using RxSwift, there are several key aspects to consider:
Setup

: Begin by setting up the test environment, including creating instances of the view model and any necessary dependencies. This may involve mocking or stubbing external dependencies, such as services or data sources.
Observables

: View models often expose observables (or Subjects) representing state or data streams. In unit tests, subscribe to these observables and verify that they emit the expected values in response to certain inputs or conditions.
Schedulers

: RxSwift provides schedulers for controlling the execution context of observables. When testing view models, itâ€™s essential to ensure that observables emit values on the correct schedulers, especially when dealing with asynchronous operations such as network requests.
Actions

: View models may contain methods or properties representing actions triggered by user interactions. In unit tests, simulate these interactions and verify that the view model behaves as expected in response.
Error Handling
: Test scenarios where observables emit errors and ensure that the view model handles them appropriately, whether by propagating them to the UI layer or handling them internally.
Completeness

: Aim to achieve comprehensive test coverage, accounting for various edge cases, error scenarios, and boundary conditions. This ensures the reliability and robustness of the view model under different circumstances.
Mocking Dependencies

: Use mocking frameworks like RxTest or XCTest to mock dependencies and simulate their behavior. This allows for better isolation of the view model under test and ensures that tests focus solely on its logic.
Assertions

: Make use of assertion methods provided by testing frameworks to validate the expected behavior of the view model. These assertions may include checking emitted values, ensuring proper error handling, and verifying interactions with dependencies.

tasks.title: Setup and write first test method

inlineContent.text: In this tutorial, letâ€™s write a test case for installment fee checking.
We have three UI error states as below:
Money amount
Bank
Card number
Create a subclass of XCTestCase.
Here, we supply an ApiServiceMock and UserDefaultServiceMock to facilitate testing permissions and simulate error codes from the server.
You should create mocks for all classes referenced in the test.
Declare all class objects needed for testing.
Declare additional helper classes to support writing test cases for this view model.
Here, create a testInstallmentFee_MoneyAmount method.
Test method name with the â€˜testâ€™ prefix is required.
Declare a TestScheduler.
TestScheduler

is a powerful tool for writing reliable and deterministic unit tests for RxSwift code that involves time-dependent operations. It allows you to simulate time in a controlled environment, making testing of reactive code more robust and efficient.
Set up all necessary conditions to be able to check the money amount.
x
is represent user press the request button.
t
is represent user input money amount.
c
is represent user switch the In-store or Online tab.
b
is represent user select a bank.
Declare an events inputs. It represents actions and inputs.
Create an scheduler events timeline from the events inputs.
In this context, there are more flows to test. We can break down the timeline into smaller parts.
We are should break down expected results follow events timeline.
Declare the expected result. Comments should match with the events timeline declared above to facilitate debugging.
Create a hot observable scheduler for input events and record the view model state. then
start
scheduler
viewModel.getState
should
skip(1)
to ignore initial value
Add
debug()
to observe scheduler emit inputs also
viewModel.getState
Compare record events from scheduler with expected results.

abstract.text: Unit testing in Swift involves breaking down code into small, testable components known as units. These units could be functions, methods, or even entire classes. By isolating these units and subjecting them to various scenarios, developers can assert the expected behavior and uncover potential bugs or regressions.
When writing unit tests for view models using RxSwift, there are several key aspects to consider:

preview-viewmodel-1-setup-2.png.alt: Declare all class objects needed for testing.
